texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Anyone working with containers has likely heard of  CoreOS  by this point Haven't heard about it? Don't despair. I'll catch you up on what you missed.
texts.text: Anyone working with containers has likely heard of  CoreOS  by this point Haven't heard about it? Don't despair. I'll catch you up on what you missed.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Fedora CoreOS offers a really fast pathway to running containers on hardware, in virtual machines, or in clouds. It delivers a lightweight operating system with all of the container technology that you need for running simple containers or launching a kubernetes deployment.
texts.text: Fedora CoreOS offers a really fast pathway to running containers on hardware, in virtual machines, or in clouds. It delivers a lightweight operating system with all of the container technology that you need for running simple containers or launching a kubernetes deployment.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But that's not the best part.
texts.text: But that's not the best part.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: CoreOS really shines due to its  immutable OS layer [^mostly_immutable]. The OS underneath your containers ships as a single unit and it automatically updates itself much like your mobile phone. An update rolls down, CoreOS sets it up as a secondary OS, reboots into that new update, and rolls back to the original one if there were any issues.
texts.text: CoreOS really shines due to its  immutable OS layer [^mostly_immutable]. The OS underneath your containers ships as a single unit and it automatically updates itself much like your mobile phone. An update rolls down, CoreOS sets it up as a secondary OS, reboots into that new update, and rolls back to the original one if there were any issues.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Many people use CoreOS as the workhorse underneath kubernetes. Red Hat uses it underneath  OpenShift  as well. It's even supported by the super light weight kubernetes distribution  k3s .
texts.text: Many people use CoreOS as the workhorse underneath kubernetes. Red Hat uses it underneath  OpenShift  as well. It's even supported by the super light weight kubernetes distribution  k3s .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But can you use CoreOS as a  pet  type instance that you use and maintain for long periods of time just like any other server? Absolutely!
texts.text: But can you use CoreOS as a  pet  type instance that you use and maintain for long periods of time just like any other server? Absolutely!

texts.orig: What's this pet stuff about?
texts.text: What's this pet stuff about?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Whether you like it or not, there's a cattle versus pets paradigm that took hold in the world of IT at some point. The basic ideas are these:
texts.text: Whether you like it or not, there's a cattle versus pets paradigm that took hold in the world of IT at some point. The basic ideas are these:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When you take care of cattle, you take care of them as a group.
texts.text: When you take care of cattle, you take care of them as a group.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: As for pets, you spend a lot of time taking care of them and playing with them.
texts.text: As for pets, you spend a lot of time taking care of them and playing with them.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A fleet of web servers could be treated like cattle. Keep lots of them online and replace any instances that have issues.
texts.text: A fleet of web servers could be treated like cattle. Keep lots of them online and replace any instances that have issues.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On the other hand, databases or tier zero systems (everyone feels if it they went down) are like pets. You carefully build, maintain, and monitor these.

texts.orig: How does CoreOS fit in?
texts.text: How does CoreOS fit in?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Many people do use CoreOS as a container hosting platform as part of a bigger system. It works really well for that. But it's great as a regular cloud server, too.
texts.text: Many people do use CoreOS as a container hosting platform as part of a bigger system. It works really well for that. But it's great as a regular cloud server, too.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can run a single node CoreOS deployment and manage containers via the tools that you know and love. For example,  docker-compose  works great on CoreOS. I even used it to host my own  Mastodon deployment .

texts.orig: You can also load up more user-friendly tools such as  portainer  to manage containers in a browser.

texts.orig: How do updates work?
texts.text: How do updates work?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are two main technologies at work here.
texts.text: There are two main technologies at work here.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First,  zincati  checks for updates to your immutable OS tree. It runs on a  configurable schedule  that you can adjust based on your preferences.
texts.text: First,  zincati  checks for updates to your immutable OS tree. It runs on a  configurable schedule  that you can adjust based on your preferences.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Second,
texts.text: Second,

texts.label: code
texts.orig: rpm-ostree
texts.text: rpm-ostree

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: handles the OS layers and switches between them at boot time. If you're running off layer A and an update comes down (layer B), that layer is written to the disk and activated on the next boot. Should there be any issues booting up layer B later,
texts.text: handles the OS layers and switches between them at boot time. If you're running off layer A and an update comes down (layer B), that layer is written to the disk and activated on the next boot. Should there be any issues booting up layer B later,

texts.label: paragraph
